content:
You have been stuck in this building for 40 days now. The reason? According to medical report, you are very mentally unstable. The society found some of you very dangerous to keep you guys around among them, so they decided to confine you here. At first, you could understand the society's action. You know you are dangerous. You even beat someone up before out of pure rage before! Living in this building was better than going to prison. Or so you thought at that time. As a day pass by, you get more angry. What did you do to deserve this? The food is terrible, the administrators force you to work all day, and your bed is only not even queen-sized. You must be raging again. You're very unstable, remember? Hell. Who cares? You need to get out of this building. This building is just like prison, disguised as your "home.".

But the administrators. They won't just let you out that easily. To ensure your safe exit, you must not let them get in your way....forever.

It is time to rage.

Welcome to Mini 1469: Rage.

Still Raging(Alive):
3. Cheery Dog, Mafia Goon, survives and win the game!

RULES

General Rules:

  1. Site-wide rules always apply here.
  2. If you have a question for me, you can always PM me. If you need to talk to me in thread, please bold your question like this so I can locate it better.
  3. You may not use hidden or encrypted text.
  4. If you have a power to edit/delete your post, don't do it. If you slip, just accept it.
  5. Play nice. I really don't mind you guys using bad languages, but don't direct them to the other players.
  6. Do not EVER discuss the ongoing games in this thread nor discuss this game elsewhere.
  7. Do not quote the PM that moderator sends you. Paraphrasing is fine till certain level.
  8. This is my color. (#408000) Don't use it.
  9. If you break these rules, I have full rights to punish you at my will. This can range from simple warning to modkill/force-replace.
  10. If I feel like it, I always have a full right to add/modify the rules. If I do, I will fully explain the reason behind such action.
  11. Most importantly, have fun!

Voting and Lynching:

  1. You vote by either using bold tag(Vote:GuyInFreezer) or using vote tag (VOTE: GuyInFreezer).
    This is how you do it.
    Code: Select all
    [b]Vote:GuyInFreezer[/b]
    [vote]GuyInFreezer[/vote]
  2. Unvote is not required to change your vote. Also, if it looks like a vote for someone, I will count it. No tricking me!
  3. Lynch happens when half of players + 1 vote the same person. Once lynch happens, the lynchee and the living players may talk until get back and post the flip.
  4. If the deadline is over before majority hits, the day will end with No Lynch.
  5. If you're nightkilled, you may post one information-less "bah" post.

Activity and Deadline:

  1. Deadline for each day is 14 days, and deadline for each night is 3 days.
  2. If you're on V/LA, please tell me beforehand by either post it in thread or PM to me.
  3. If you don't post here for 48 real hours, I will prod you. Failure to receive prod within 24 hours or receiving 3+ prods in game will cause force-replacement.
  4. If you do not submit a night action, it will count as No Action.
  5. If I have to extend deadline, I will. If I do, I will post it on thread.

At least one of you will get this PM.

Welcome to Mini Normal 1469: Rage, Name!

You are a Vanilla Townie.

Abilities:
  • None
Win Condition:
  • You win when the threats to the town are eliminated.

Role PMs are being sent right now...Not anymore!
Role PMs are sent.
The game will start either when 11/13 confirm or 2 days have passed (8:12 PM EST), whichever comes first.

Countdown: (expired on 2013-07-02 20:12:40)

Administrators are not stupid. At least, that's what they think. At least, they were smart enough to figure out that the revolt was nigh.

June 30, 2013 11:58 PM
Room 1469


The moderator, who had a nickname of "GuyInFreezer" for unknown reason, was working with his computer when few unknown people barged into his room.

"Wha- Who-who are you people?"

"Sorry, mister. But you know about the 'certain activity,' correct?"

"N-No..! I'm just a harmless moderator! I don't know nothing about that 'certain activity' you guys are talking about!"

"Hah. Double-negative! That means you DO know about the revolt!"

"Eh? Wha-"

"As a moderator, you have betrayed us by taking side with those miserable barbarians."

"Wait a moment. English is my second language! You got it all wro-"

GuyInFreezer, Just an innocent moderator, paid his price for using bad grammar Night 0.

July 1, 2013 3:00 PM
Public Dining Hall


Everyone was waiting in the dining hall until the investigation was over.
They were grieving the moderator's death until one person spoke up.

"Hey maybe the administrators killed him."

That one sentence was enough to set the fire to the short fuse called rage to the dwellers's heart.

Day 1 starts now!
Deadline: July 17, 2013 3:00 PM EST

In post 141, Nul wrote:When I said "Cheery I think you're scum" that was an attempt to fish for reaction tells.

So I should therefore have asked why, got no true answer and voted you? Interesting failed ploy.

I'll respond to other stuff later, but I'd just like to point out another pet peeve/theory rant of mine that I feel like I wind up pointing out/ranting about in almost every game I'm in these days, although every time slightly differently ~_~

It's really, really stupid as town to start looking for associative tells at this stage (this is directed at Team Rocket for the "we agree they might be bussing" thing). The primary reason for that is... well, first let's assume there are 3 scum in the game. From your point of view, if you are town, that's 12 other people to read, with a 3/12 = 1/4 shot at hitting scum. As for associations, there are 12 choose 2 = 66 possible different pairs of people that aren't you, and only 3 pairs (scum A + scum B, scum A + scum C, scum B + scum C) that are correct. I.E., if you accuse two players of bussing, your brute odds of being right are 3/66 = 1/22. Essentially, what this means is that, in very vague terms, you should be about 5.5 times more "confident" in scumtells that you see between people you think are bussing than you would be in scumtells on an individual level before you declare the people in question to be probably bussing. Even if it's the only scenario that the two hydra's heads agree is likely... well, see my next paragraph. Plus, you would still need to have extremely strong justifications for calling it a bus, or as Carl Sagan said, "Extraordinary claims require extraordinary proof."

Furthermore, there is no "inherent" way to distinguish between a T -> T interaction and a T -> S interaction, because a townie will act based on what they THINK of the other person's alignment, not based on what the other person's alignment actually is. So hunting for interactions by characterizing the interaction as TvT or TvS as opposed to characterizing the individuals involved as town or as scum is also very silly. I mean, you could theoretically try to characterize a person's behavior as scum talking to a townie, but at that point, you're saying much more about that individual than you are about the person you're saying is town, so you're basically reading them on an individual level.

If you want to say "I think this interaction is scum V scum" that's all well and good. However, your actual actions (by which I mean votes) should NOT be motivated by thinking that X is a bus on day one before anyone has flipped. Associative tells are awesome if you know that one of the people involved is scum.

Nul wrote:There is no point in announcing townreads, you might as well be giving a list to mafia telling them who to kill.

Strongly disagree. I'm gonna take a page from petroleumjelly's playbook here:

1) Scum are smart enough to figure out what people are obvious town on their own; they don't need our help, and giving them our help won't help them significantly.
2) Not all scum take out the most obvious town people automatically. Some will base kills based on people they think are power roles, some will base kills based on those who suspect them, etc.
3) Outing townreads involves outing justifications for those townreads, which allows others to read the person giving the townreads.
4) Outing townreads allows the person townreading to defend the person they townread if they come under attack (rather poignant example)
5) Outing townreads allows other people to comment on them, criticize them, reaffirm them, etc. Just because a person has a townread, doesn't mean that townread is correct... just like you would want other people to comment on a scumread you have, you would want them to comment on a townread you have.
6) Just like when you fos someone, you can observe someone's reaction to being townread and judge it to better read them.
7) Often, just talking about townreads can stimulate other discussion effectively.

no.

There are, by the definition of mafia as the clash of an informed minority and an informed majority, more town than mafia. Why presumption should be that a given person is guilty is beyond me.

Besides, I don't think the idea of presumption really works in a setting of mafia either way. I think the presumptive state in a game of mafia has to be whatever we assume in the absence of any posts, or in pregame - i.e., from my point of view, my presumption would be "i am town and everyone else has approximately a 1/4 chance of being scum." Then those probabilities change as the game goes on.

Aaaanyway. It is absolutely up to bestwillcui to start being helpful, but that doesn't mean we can scumread him until he becomes helpful. And Miss Stranger, you really did say that your vote wasn't a policy lynch and then go on to explain how it was, in fact, a policy lynch... you said it was a "rule of play" and that lurkers were "always" null reads. Rule and policy are the same thing; if it's a rule of play that you vote for lurkers, then it is a policy vote.

My opinion on best right now, and I think by far the "best" opinion to have on him, is an opinion of "well, i really don't know and i hope that he contributes so that i *can* know."

I have absolutely had games where I had long periods of time where I could post almost none because of a combination of being very busy and being really tired. Lurking is not, on its own, a tell, even if he also has signs of paying attention to the game - I've had games (as town) where I have the time/energy to keep up with the game, but not the time/energy to contribute for good periods of time.

foodtell is a sort of specific variation of a more general tell, where someone spends a lot of time talking about what they did or will do while not posting. An early example that first caught attention in a game and actually prompted the title went something like

"I will be back in a while. I'm making a roasted tomato sauce for hand-tossed pizza atm."

The focus is on the activity, not on the delay in reply/catch-up.

The same player in an earlier game had said something like "I'll catch up in a couple hours. I gotta feed people."

The focus is on the delay, not what he was doing instead of posting.

I've made it something of a mission to obliterate this tell by foodtelling as town whenever I can.

July 19, 9:22 PM


The discussion seemed like it would never end.

There were a lot of accusations flying around, and a lot of fist trades happened.

Sometimes, a person left, and a different person entered a room, but no one seemed to care.

Finally, people started to gang up on one person.

"Hello there, 'pieceofpecanpie.' We heard that you are a good baker."

"Indeed I am. I make a good pecan pie. That's why the nickname 'pieceofpecanpie' stuck to me."

"Is that so? Then why have you never baked one for us?"

"Huh?"

"I think we know the answer. You are sided with those administrator dogs. You bake a nice pie for them, but not even a piece for us!"

"Wai- wait a minute! Just because I never made one for you, that doesn't mean-"

"Die, scum!"

"Nooooooooo!!"

Soon, pieceofpecanpie turned into a bloody corpse by the angry mob. It seemed like someone was making a grin, but no one cared.

Hello everyone. Good to be here. First game on the site. I am almost done reading through the thread, and will post my thoughts shortly. I've taken lots of notes so feel free to get my thoughts on anyone (some posts more detailed than others)/ask for links to games I've played on other sites/etc.

Biggest thing I'm going to post about in a second right off the bat is that TR is on the top of my scum list and that (as of page 27), Naomi seems to be a favorite to lynch today which I don't like.

So my case against TR and my defense of Naomi coming shortly-ish.

Ugh, back to square 1...

gm looks more like a vig kill than multiball/sk, which I guess is a good thing.

Don't really want to lynch Naomi any more. Team Rocket/cheery are the closest to scumreads I have right now.

Looking forward to hear your thoughts, surviva.

I also might have to revisit the morph slot.

Why Team Rocket Is My Biggest Suspect:

Right from the early going, my notes on him have always been that he is getting involved with a lot of bandwagons with very little content to support that (except for just going along with what others said, and those arguments he's backseated have often buggy which supports that he's more concerned with rubbing elbows with townies than with scumhunting; I can give more specific examples if asked). It could just be bad villagering, but I differentiate it from, say, Naomi-Tan because he is not putting his neck out there. Just kinda going along with the town's sentiments on issues. Even when Naomi was bandwagoning, she put her neck out there by saying, ~“I'm doing this because I'm bandwagoning, which is good to get us out of RVS.” TR is mostly just going, ~“Yeah, I'll go with this guy that the town is already not okay with for these reasons that mirror the reasons that the town is going after them.” I can't find a single example where he went against general town sentiment at the time. Loved Naomi when others had expressed they loved Naomi, was ~2 to just about every bandwagon without great reasoning behind it, etc. Those were my early notes.

The times that he was pressed to actually stand on his own legs, I've hated what he's had to say. First example is with bussing/hydra discord on CD reads/general thoughts on Nul vs CD, but I'll save that for now. The next example is when he's pushing for BestWillcui (with 3 already on the wagon) Post 308: "Firstly this is not a very good hypothetical since this entire game would be different if we were scum (because our role would be different and so would at least one other role in the game which would probably cause the vast majority of posts to be different)

And while I could see a potential scum player pushing a lynch on a potential town bestwillcui pushing a lynch on him

But that doesn't mean bestwillcui doesn't still look scummy? Like people (or at least I) are suspicious of him for broader reasons than just "he's lurking."

I feel like we're wasting our time arguing about this."

Translation: ~”Let me open with an oblique point involving chaos theory because what the fuck else could I open this post with that would be more of a derail of this discussion. Anyway, while you are right that it would be good for the scums to lynch him . . . (sentence dissolves into unintentional grammar fail). Other people think BestWillcui is scummy, and I agree. That's a good enough reason to lynch him. Let's lynch him.”~*

It's like 3 scumtells rolled in one. Deflection, counterpoint that never ends up being a counterpoint, total backseating, and then finishing on deflection again. S/he just doesn't feel that comfortable on the spotlight

*NOTE: ~” means that I am paraphrasing or, in this case, taking the piss quite a bit with what someone's saying.

Game style remained static throughout the day. Just rubbing elbows with all the town picks. Not starting any bandwagons himself, just saying, “I could see that, vote!” (Sorry, I notice that I'm starting to repeat myself, but the fact I note this 3 different times over the course of one day seems worth leaving in my working notes). MOST IMPORTANTLY 3 of those people he voted for on Day 1 are confirmed villagers from my perspective: Nul/Kalimar, bestwillcui/PoPP, Reecer/me (this logic obviously doesn't work from other players' perspective, since I am not a confirmed villager as far as you guys are concerned). All 3 of these players gathered large bandwagons (I'm pretty sure the 3 largest wagons of the day), so these aren't to be taken lightly. Townspeople make mistakes of course, but the fact that all of these were with limited reasoning and just coast along with the town's general sentiments at the time make this a very problematic record.

I actually really REALLY like a TR/CD scum combination. You can't expect scum to play completely transparently, so why not throw CD on there as one of his many suspects. One fellow scum on a list of 5 is right about the sweet spot for a game this size, and he is the one that he never votes for. Not only do they not vote for CD, but they hedge their bets by having hydra disagreement on the matter, by pointing out as part of their indictment that CD does play unorthodox in general and by introducing CD as a suspect as part of an unlikely (as far as the town is concerned; impossible as far as they're concerned) bussing scenario. All of this makes this very easy to revoke when any actual pressure actually comes on CD, especially if Nul has already come up villager at any point.

Only problem with this is that CD's very first non-RVS vote was for TR (first vote was for Rhyx/Good Morning). The post where Cheery made this vote (7/3, 21:33 #129) Cheery uses the hydra disagreement on whether to vote Nul or CD as his reasoning. Again, this is something that CD can easily go back on once TR explains their point better or just moves on from the bussing idea altogether. This also comes at a stage in the game (still RVS-ish) and a situation (OMGUS-ish) where they can both move on quickly to better targets whenever the town inevitably gets bored of the Nul/CD interaction, and sure enough, they both did. Cheery had unvoted within two pages and about a day and a half, conveniently enough as part of a reaction to discredit someone else who was voting TR (granted, it was a very easy vote to discredit, and if anything scum should actually defer to letting this one slide and let others point it out).

I know I'm spending a lot of ink on a very early association theory, but TR makes a lot of sense, and he works in some scummy pairings with our PoE pool. For now I like lynch TR today, lynch CD tomorrow until convinced otherwise.

I have thoughts on more players that could be scummish than just TR, but I need to do my iso'ing homework and such on them first, and before that, I'd like to talk about Naomi.

BTW, Since from my perspective, the 3 largest bandwagons on Day 1 are all confirmed villagers, I will be giving those lists some very thorough consideration.

Nul: Got up to L-2, maybe worse if not confirmed; voters are: Team Rocket | Reecer6/me | bestwillcui/PoPP | Miss Stranger/Good Morning | Yates
ME: Got up to L-2, voters are: Naomi-Tan | implosion | Team Rocket | Nul/Kalimar | Metal Sonic/Shamrock
PoPP: Lynched, voters are: Team Rocket | implosion | Cheery Dog | serrapaladin | Effulgence | Kalimar | Shamrock

I think my lynch list is the least likely to contain 2+ mafia on it because it started as a split wagon with Nul and then once Nul is confirmed, it looks atrocious for the scum from that list to snap move over to another player's bandwagon to clinch the lynch and have them turn over villager as well. It was gonna take some massaging to justify a move like that, and when a bandwagon built for bestwillcui (who was doing no favors for himself), it was an easier option.

Obviously, it's the least likely to contain scum from your perspective too, since I'm not a confirmed villager.

On Naomi-Tan Being a Poor Suspect:

Right from the very very beginning, I've had Naomi-Tan tagged as just a bad, “I see the scumminess in everyone” villager. Though I have my reasonings for this in the beginning of the day, I think the case strengthens as the day moves on. In the first 10 pages, she's jumping on everyone's case, starting lynchwagons, jumping on lynch wagons, implicating everyone, etc, but unlike TR, she's leading the charge, being assertive and is really putting her neck out there, frequently going against town sentiment. She even makes a bold point when she's jumping on wagons (again, decidedly different from TR), being like, ~"Hey, I'm being the second vote here, yes that's right, I'm jumping on a wagon, and x reason is why."~ Basically, doing the exact opposite of what scum will generally try to do on day one, which is stay out of the spotlight. As the narrative moves on, I find it VERY unlikely that she is the type of scum who would be encouraging herself or be encouraged by others to bring the spotlight on herself.

She cooled down a lot since gaining town cred. That sounds suspicious when worded that way, but I think that would be a very strange strategy for a scum to take on. “Hey, I'll just light a bunch of fires and instigate a bunch of shit, and the second people start pointing fingers at me, I'll just not defend myself and let everyone sully my name uncontested.” It's usually the exact other way around: make yourself sparse until people start to notice how sparse you are and then defend yourself. I just can't see how getting yourself implicated in a bunch of shit and then disappearing just when it's time to make sense of it fits into a scum strategy. It seems odd to give town cred for it, but I'd say it's null inactivity.

Then, she explodes back on the scene and makes a bunch of silly mistakes. The amount of slip-ups she's making and the amount of dead paths she's sniffed down in all of her many words of posts makes me think that she wouldn't be trusted by the mafia to go so balls to the wall in making accusations. Being on a mafia team means that you are not on an island: you have several people coaching you, and Naomi doesn't at all feel coached. I suppose the counterargument would be that she went balls to the wall early, got reprimanded, disappeared off the face of the earth, then when the heat got turned up too much to go unignored (not buying this given she didn't come until several pages after the heat came on, yet she came before votes built up, so I have no idea what the boiling point was for her to explode back on the scene; just seems like null randomness), and then came back on the scene defending herself. I don't buy this counterargument for a lot of reasons though (too long a lag between her going balls to the wall and how long it would take for her to be reprimanded [over a week real time], the timing of her reappearance as already covered, the fact that her explosion back on the scene does not seem coached or prepared at all in spite of how much time had gone for it to be prepared). I really really really think all signs point to a flailing townie.

Voting pattern doesn't fit a scum well (see post 815). The only one of the three big bandwagons she jumped on was mine.

Effulgence was her biggest fan of the regular posters toward the end of Day 1 with pressure mounting against her to be lynched on Day 2. It would be a very ballsy level to shoot your biggest and most trusted defendant when you are probably the favorite to be lynched going into Day 2. I can't see why the mafia would shoot Good Morning given there were zero special tells and that it's a fresh player who hasn't shown much either way, so with how many likely villagers there are (eg: Effulgence) I would feel near certain they would take their chances with him. So either way, it doesn't seem likely that a team with Naomi on it shot either of these players.

Others to talk about after PoE:

Cheery Dog – I think the silly argument with Nul give him a huge out early on. He could spend much of the first part of the day just defending himself against a silly accusation of ~"Omg, you didn't ask the quesiton I expected you to."~ His post count shot up without saying much more than, "So what? Big whoop?"

As such, my early notes are that he could just be feasting on the easy fodder, just defending himself against silly accusations, and as such doesn't need to associate himself with anyone. When asked to move past the tunnel of Nul, he said that Naomi is “Nullish-Town. Probably haven't looked that much at her - but from what I've been reading, it seems like town intent.” Very non-committal, and goes along with what the rest of the town thinks at the time and, of course, says that he hasn't much looked into it. None of this is suspicious, it's just either null-town, or a very convenient line for a scum to take to not garner suspicion.

The fact that he went cold once he stopped having the easy fodder posts corroborates this potential narrative. In post 532 (that's with a 5, people) he's still talking about the Nul/CD bussing theory as if that's still the only salient thing that's happened so far in the game.

I have no problem finding scum pairings for him. Anyone who has listed scum reads has done so in a very conflicted manner (sometimes literally split on the issue, in the case of hydras, but often just in an "eh, I could see it, but it's how he always is" sorta way).

Fits into the voting narrative okay. He's in the middle of the wagon on PoPP, and didn't vote on either of the other big wagons.


Morph the Cat – My general impression when reading through was that he stayed out of the fray quite well and followed a good scum's line very well.

He's managed to be not even remotely associated with anyone that the town is reasonably suspicious of. Seriously, the only person who's so much as quote his posts, it seems, is serrapaladin, who is a strong-ish townread (imo) who was suspicious of Morph/NEC. He's managed to be so far out of the portrait without being included in just about anyone's inactive list at just about any point. I mean, just because someone isn't suspicious doesn't mean that they are suspicious--that would be a ridiculous argument—but I can see this as a very good mafia's ideal game.

Looking back through the ISO, I can kinda see how he achieves this. His posts that aren't just friendly what-have-yous seem to often be stepping in on feuds and placating them with little blurbs that keep their distance (eg: [*post]66[/post], [*post]87[/post], [*post]90[/post], [*post]110[/post], [*post]126[/post], it goes on). He's commenting on the dispute (which is the main ordeal at hand at the time), yet if you were to interview anyone afterward, I would hardly expect that anyone would list NEC as a central character in the thread, or even a big outside influence. They would just remember that he was there and he made some comments of some sort. Kinda float like a butterfly, sting like a bee-ish.

Then the thread becomes a headache to read and he just kinda starts playing the town's administrative assistant: following up on people who said they had more to say, asking some questions, +1'ing the fact that gender pronouns don't matter. That goes on for ~200 posts (most of the game at that point), and then he comes back with some contributions to logic and even a vote for pitoli (now serrapaladin). When he starts to seem the most townish is with [*post]464[/post], as it is literally a bold statement to make at that point of the game. This would have gained massive town cred with me.....if it had come BEFORE serrapaladin started to make the case. As it stands, serrapaladin was quickly becoming a reputable person to side with (ie, not risky to jump on even though other reputable people felt strongly against her), and Naomi's iso would clearly show to NEC that there's an opportunity afoot to thoroughly sully someone.

He was early to the show and did stick out as much as he'd ever let himself show with the Naomi push, but given how big Naomi's warts were, if this is the most townish thing I can say for NEC, then I'm really not likin' NEC.

Then a new hydra partner replaces-in, and he continues to be an overall nice lad to talk to and is willing to help you out on some terminology here and there if you'd like.

Finally, we get some associations via a list of every town member. The thing that sticks out is that other than PoPP and TR, everyone he's suspicious of comes with a hydra dissonance. I've never played with hydras, so let this come with a grain of salt, but I think these would be easy to backpedal on, and I've already seen hydras convince “themselves” on a player or two without it drawing suspicion. The fact that these avenues exist for backing out of suspicions, several permutations of scum teams seem very reasonable to me: morph/CD, morph/MS, morph/implosion, etc. Morph/TR would have to be very ballsy because he scummed him just as the heat was coming off TR (and before it came back on in full force).

The voting narrative doesn't fit as neatly as the others. It could be reasonably expected, though, that there would be at least one scum who isn't a bandwagon-hopping fiend.


Shamrock – It's been pointed out at length that Metal Sonic was full of fluff, and it's been pointed out that he's done it to a degree to where it's such first-level scumming that we could reasonably expect better from most mafia, so I'll skip the notes I have on him that get into all that. The things is that I kinda got the sense that he's banking on his meta to save him, and may even be parodying himself a bit. He's outright antagonizing and self-deprecating in his way of being lazy villager, especially all over page 15. [*post]354[/post]: Metal Sonic is just like at Stephen Colbert-level oblivious self-irony: ~“He only digs up reads when asked, which is why I'm going to bandwagon someone that you told me to look into.”~ He had several similar posts with self-effacing irony in them that he at least pretended to be oblivious to. I've sometimes had daydreams of being a lazy villager so that one day I could get that sweet sweet vindicating PM that says I am mafia, and just spend the whole game being like “Fuck you guys, I always play like this. Deal with it,” and Sonic seems like he might be taking it to that extreme.

But maybe his town games are this cocky as well, and even if they aren't, this is a weak read. I'm just not totally buying the “surely no scum would be this stupid” argument because Sonic might think it's playing into his image.

Then, Shamrock comes in and my pathos totally splits with my logos. I think Shamrock is nothing but good vibes. Articulate, making thorough posts when neither asked nor expected to—overall, plays in a way I appreciate a lot. I could, however, see how it could fit into a scum strategy. He had a lot to make up for taking over for the Village Idiot who had taken some heat. Shamrock even makes a meta-excuse before making his big replacement catch-up post (going as far as to say his post goes against his religion and that he should self-flagellate; not that I'm oblivious to the exaggeration and humor, I'm just saying there's no room to doubt the meta-excusing that's going on), so clearly he's going to an inordinate level of trouble to clean his image. Not that trying to make a village not hate you is alignment-dependent; getting lynched sounds like an unpleasant thing for townie and mafia alike, but again, it's actions that are in line with mafia, so I'm leaving him in the Could Go either Way Bin.

My viscera continues to like his line of questioning on page 32, and he's a bit more aggressive with posters than mafia generally like to be on Day 1. Then again, given that he's mostly doing it with now-confirmed villagers who had fallen into malhumor with the town at a time when the lynch was already decided, it seems reasonable that scum could ride this wave as well. It all sends out good vibes because there's no cognitive dissonance: his town perspective (“well that looks scummy”) and his scum perspective (“I can implicate a townie at a time where I'm basically freerolling”) are perfectly aligned.

So I have no intention of bolding his name anytime soon, but I'm not going to lose credence over pairings that involve him, and as the process of elimination narrows, he might become a good option in mid-to-late game.

I think there are plenty of pairings that make sense for him. Just about all of my suspects have been giving him the old “no reads either way” on him or have been ignoring him altogether. His voting narrative fits perfectly (though, honestly, just about anyone could have clinched PoPP's fate).


Implosion – Once he gets into game specific posts (especially [*post]112[/post] on), there's a lot I like that gave him some early town cred. I think he made a lot of legitimate attacks on Team Rocket which led me to give him a ton of town cred early on. He's also one of the only players who doesn't think a big fuss needs to be made about the early Nul/CD shit fling, which made me feel like I wasn't the only not taking crazy pills. So I was all about implosion early on.

However, my general impression reads don't fare quite as well. He talks a lot about the game in general terms, especially early on. This is very safe territory for scum because you can photocopy posts like this in every game you play in, regardless of alignment, and look like you're contributing. ~”Sure let's get in a semantics argument about the phrase 'in this town'; let me reply to you with an exaggeratedly literal interpretations of your question.”~ He even admits to (not really the right word because it's not incriminating, per se) that he's basically photocopying his argument on how association tells are useless. It's a whole lot of saying things that you can't really argue are wrong, but then again aren't salient to the game at hand.

He has 16 of the first 100 posts (almost tripling his expected share, for those counting at home), and all but a clause here and a clause there is stuff that could be said by anyone in any game. First 100 posts though, so fair enough, but he seemed to be at his most active when there was easy fodder. Not just talking about first 100 posts, either; also [*post]144[/post], [*post]178[/post], [*post]210[/post], [*post]273[/post], [*post]309[/post] (boasting, then semantics, then self-reference), I don't know it gets exhausting to list all the examples of helping people with html code and talking about playstyles and general game theory and all that. The point isn't that any of it is suspicious, just that it's a great way for scum and townies alike to gain cred-through-wordcount without taking any real risks. As the day progresses, talk about general play slows and he disappears off the face of the earth. This could very well be that the cavalry showed up in the form of Effulgence, so now he can go off to bigger and better things, but it's also a convenient line for scum to take.

More importantly, among the posts that I really liked, there were just enough things that I disagreed strongly on to keep me concerned. Just as examples (I'm not actually in the mood for arguing these points as it would be irrelevant to the issue at hand) his large post on association tells is a misuse of probability principles, I disagreed strongly with thinking that early role calls for inactives is scummy (though this might be playstyle difference because I come from games where Day 1 is ~3 pages), got a little frustrated that he couldn't see how Naomi defending townies is only beknighting for those who know that she is defending a townie (even though we're both on the same page that it doesn't make Naomi a scum), etc. I realize that some of this is weakened due to their association with emotion, it just seems to strike that perfect balance of “that makes perfect sense” with “that is THIS close to being right, but there's a dangerous fallacy that leads to the completely wrong answer.” This makes me concerned that he's reasonable enough and posting enough to gain trust, and through reasonable twists of logic is able to opportunely guide the village down the wrong paths.

Then, of course, this hypothesis fits nicely into the voting narrative. I'd imagine if he's the type who's strategy is to go hard on arguments that don't give him cognitive dissonance, then it makes sense he would be leading the charge against townies who he thought he could reasonably represent as suspicious (instead of backseating). He was early to the wagon for me (going after Reecer from a very early stage) and was middle-to-earlyish to the post-BestWillCui PoPP wagon. He was, however, strongly against Nul being a baddie.

All this probably adds up to a mostly null read. He is my 4th most likely candidate, though (and I'm not whizzing my panties over the 3rd candidate), so I'm keeping fairly suspicious of my null-to-ever-so-slightly scum reads.

TR and implosion make a poor pairing, by the way. He's really the first to call out TR on some things that are making him the current lynch candidate, yet by day's end, he had defended him so much (without any vote pressure being applied) that it's a terrible way to dissociate from TR. Basically, implosion has gone after TR at the times when he could least leverage the advantage of doing so (very early Day 1, starting the wagon after everyone else had already said they like the lynch) and defended TR at the times when he could least leverage the advantage of the defense (when there's no chance he's going to get lynched anyway). Basically, implosion's drawing a huge association between the two and accepting none of the advantages of doing so. This would obviously be a bad and presumptive reason to keep implosion off my PoE list, though, so here he is.

That's an understandable narrative. It would certainly very easily hold up in the court of law. That doesn't mean that it's potential for scum doesn't affect the likelihood that you could be scum. Trying to explain that divulged myself into writing notes for a massive post that's mostly about general theory and mostly about a soft argument on a player that I don't think people have interest (nor necessarily should have that much interest) reading a ton about today, so to try to reply to you without derailing potentially better discussion. It's not satisfactory, but feel free to ask more because I love talking game theory.

Cliffnote 1: Instead of doing townreads/scumreads, I tend to moreso look at an entire narrative and punish any lines that a scum person could take advantage of. The ideal of this strategy is to try to mitigate any advantages that scum could gain on the town to the point that their optimal strategy is perfectly balanced/unexploitable, which is a mere zero-sum gain. This level of perfection isn't realistic, but a perfectly unexploitable strategy for scum is basically just to play as any other helpful villager, even to the extent of not favoring their scum partners in anyway. Obviously this ideal, or any shadow of it, is a huge advantage for the village.

What's cliffnoted out of here is examples of how the scum's statistical advantages get assuaged by forcing them to vote in more balanced ways, produce more balanced scum lists, etc. These are simple, basic examples, but making sure people don't get away with other exploitative lines as scum is just a simple extrapolation from that.

Cliffnote 2: A big diversion on how I noticed that "policy lynches" get a bad name around here, when that's probably because people generally take this strategy to be "lynch a random one of the three inactives," which is terrible. There are good ways to mitigate the advantage scum get when there are inactive players. This part is truly, truly irrelevant, but ask away.

Cliffnote 3: An explanation of how these reads/narratives/whatever you want to call them will (assuming good analysis) just about always coincide with an improved chance that that player is scum. A bastardized version of explaining this is, I guess, to say that any good line for scum to take is going to be a reasonably standard line for any good scum to take (so long as it isn't a non-thinking player, a weird line, a very bold or risky move, etc; this should be considered in the "good analysis" that we assumed), whereas anything that stands out to an observer and remains suspicious after good analysis is going to be at least a bit non-standard (eg: even if it's understandable, it's not like it's standard that townies just clock out once another good townie replaces-in...though I am new to replace-in games).

Then I get into how this ratio (of scum likelihood:town likeihood) can be further weighted based on how frequent suspicious activity/scumreads/etc are in a given town. In theory, this is actually a quotient that literally weights that number, but in simple terms, it's kinda Occam's Razor. If this were a town where so many people were suspicious, then the simplest explanations with the least unlikely caveats would rise to the top. In a town where we're cobbling together scum possibilities, more elaborate schemes of crafty scumming necessarily become more valuable. I think this is more of the latter town, so anything that makes me say, "I could see scum doing that" is rising to the top.
Oh good, cliffnotes that are longer than 95% of other people's posts.  Welcome to the forums, surviva316, you almost lasted 20 posts before everyone hated you.

I think the latest push for serrapaladin is misguided. I didn't post anything on him yet, so here are my reads broken up by day.

Notes from yesterday: Replaced an inactive with lots of activity. It's not just the activity that makes him a villager, though. It's the fact that he's leading the charge on people that no one suspected before, and he's doing it in a way that's not just spraying and trying to get any bandwagon started that he can. He explicitly didn't like either of the bandwagons that had started (both of which are confirmed villagers from my perspective), and his Would Like to Lynch List was just two people. One of those players, Naomi-Tan, was at the top of a lot of likely villagers lists and was yet to get any heat. Even though I feel pretty strongly that Naomi is town, I still don't think trying to build a charge against her with no previous support is a very scum thing to do at all, especially at a point of the game where there were two bandwagons to choose from and a scum very easily could have just said, “Well, I don't think so-and-so is a villager, and I think that the other guy who has a bandwagon on him is as per Post #{some post written by someone else} I think the other guy is, so I'll go with that one.” I'm exaggerating a bit, but I still think that serrapaladin's actions given the timing of it is SO much more in line with a villager than it is with a scum...even a very good, very confident one. (For the sake of a counterexample, I've gone back over Shamrock's replace-in posts that I originally felt pretty good about and would say it's much much easier fodder for scum; give a couple of strong town reads and then backseat a liked townie's case against a now-confirmed townie [ie: piggybacking Eff's argument against PPP]). Serra also did some investigation on Morph the Cat (then Effen), whom no one had seriously looked into yet.

Attacking untouched players is sure to get a lot of questions aimed your way and can only convince anyone after typing out several posts worth of reasoning and clarification, which is putting himself in the spotlight far more than any mafia member would naturally like to. Obviously, a very good scum might attempt it, but it's beneficial for the town to force scum to play this way, so I'm fine with giving out brownie points for it; besides, the "he might be good scum" line is only useful in late game after all of the player's bandwagons flip town and we have any actual hard reasoning to question their motives).

Notes from today: He started today by misdirecting attention from the easy target and trying to get discussion going on one of Cheery Dog/Yates/Morph. Mentioning Yates marks the 3rd time that he mentioned someone that no one had seriously considered as scum. Again, bucking the easy lynch to push for unpopular lynches is extremely villagery. Also, the motivation of pressuring potential tough scum instead of just making a day out of it is completely counterproductive as a wolf. It's not impossible, but again, rewarding players for doing things that are counterproductive to wolves makes the town tougher to exploit.

His latest paradox on whether or not he had a scum read on Cheery Dog is tough to follow, but it more-so follows his narrative that he's trying to pressure players who would be tough wolves instead of making an easy day of it (which is an extremely town motivation) than it follows any sort of scum narrative. (I started to type out all my thoughts on each permutation of serra scum/CD town, serra scum/CD scum, serra town/CD town and serra town/CD scum and demonstrate on an event-by-event basis how serra town makes more sense regardless, but it got long, so hopefully my point's evident; feel free to ask for elaboration).

Of course, if TR flips scum, then all of this could be seen as a ploy to divert attention, and in that case we can analyze 912 and 971 to death (still tend to think it's town), but if serra's scuminess is contingent on TR's scuminess, then TR is necessarily at least as likely to be scum and, thus, should necessarily be lynched before serra. All of the value of lynching serra before TR is derived from the permutation of TR town/serra scum.

The big question is whether we're in a 3-1-9 scenario or a 2-1-10 scenario.

If it's the former scenario, we need to lynch scum today. If it's the latter, a Serial Killer lynch would be better.

A scan of the archives shows that 3-1-x is most common by far (in setups with a Serial Killer). Three power roles tend to be most common in this scenario, however there are several setups that go against this trend. History isn't necessarily going to provide all the answers, because as far as I can see Innocent Child and Serial Killer have (perhaps appropriately?) not met before. However, some observations which may be of note:

- Jack of all Trades and Jailkeeper have never been combined in a Mini Normal as far as I can see. Same with the Innocent Child (though both Innocent Child and Jack of all Trades seem to be less frequently used roles here).
- Commuter has only appeared in about six Mini Normal games total. Of these, only one featured a Serial Killer. However, the moderator of this game was in that game.
- Odd-Night Doctor is also quite rare - about three instances total including a Mafia Odd-Night Doctor. There are quite a few instances of Odd-Night roles being twinned with Even-Night roles, but plenty of games just have an Odd-Night role (if there is one at all).
- Jailkeeper and Serial Killer have appeared together a few times.

The question to you (and others) is this - are we in 2-1-10 or 3-1-9?

13p games with an sk are extremely hard to balance. 1-shot cop and 1-shot tracker just isn't enough town investigative power to deal with 4 scum. Interestingly, if you have a "typical" 3/13 or 2/9 scum, adding an sk for a VT doesn't change the scum win chance much at all, but really screws over town. If you have a setup that's more or less balanced as 3:10, that same setup is more or less balanced as 1:3:9 if scum loses their ability to night kill, but horrendously unbalanced if scum keeps their kill.

The big problem I had was that I had reads I couldn't build cases around. I don't think I could have gotten Yates/morph/Cheery lynched had I tried. I should have argued against the TR lynch, but had no one to substitute, given I had copped Naomi. Incidentally, that was another problem. I think my complete flip on reading Naomi was already quite obvious, but I had no idea how to crumb that my joat had a cop, and that I got an inno on Naomi. Fery, did you guys figure out I had copped Naomi?

Not lynching claimed scum, regardless of setup spec, is really unforgivable. That being said, 2 mislynches shouldn't be able to doom the town, but I guess that's the swinginess of multiball.
